userreviews.userReview: Well, it's finished - it's a really short story, like, Reader's Digest type short, but I've been wanting to release it for a while now. If anyone wants a free PDF copy to read, just send me an email at gasmaskproductionsbooks@gmail.com :)

While a disillusioned weatherman's career may be coming to an end, Hurricane Irma sweeps across Florida, in another short story from the always entertaining Rebecca McNutt. Her characters are as well developed as ever & there are some good surprises along the way.
I just saw the 2016 movie of Christine Chubbuck, so I was really in the mood for a more uplifting outcome to her story, and this book really delivers!

Perfect timing because I just saw "Kate Plays Christine" on Netflix last night. This is a good brief read, perfect for a ride to work. I also remember Hurricane Irma. Is this the first fiction story written about it?

This book could easly be renamed "Mid-Life Crisis for Beginners". A local celebrity finds himself on the verge of being forcibly retired from his beloved career. It takes a spooky and sad old VCR tape to send him spiraling into retaliation.

Anyone see Kate Plays Christine? If you have, you'll want to read this. It's actually the very first book I've ever read on Christine Chubbuck herself, but it's really not about her so much as it's about a weatherman having a mid-life crisis.

Like most of McNutt's works, this short story manages to find a way to be gothic amidst the terror of a deadly hurricane sweeping through Florida. A middle-aged anchorman finds himself swimming out into the flooded streets to make a statement about the ruthless nature of his career.

There's a sort of pain and longing that comes with a mid-life crisis. I've got to say it's strange that a nineteen-year-old would be the one to best portray the innermost feelings of getting "past it", but this story just really clicks together good to me.

With Hurricane Irma so recent, this short story is as relevant as ever and tells of a weatherman going through a mid-life crisis, having a mental breakdown after viewing an unusual tape. Will he survive, or be washed away by the wind and water?
I spent a number of years in Florida, and hearing about Irma on the news was a real sin. I never realized how much I needed a book like this to bring some light to a dark situation.
Liked it a lot, but it was so short and I wanted to hear more about the tape. Loved the Hurricane Irma imagery, too.
A quick, easy and timely read. Fans of the movie "Network" and the 2016 biopic "Christine" will really get a kick outta it.
A little too sad and lamenting for my taste,,,,, but a good story anyway with nice morals about life and love.

Is this the only book so far written by Rebecca that isn't horror? I don't know but it was so cute! Bud was a lovable grouch and his rise against replacement was amazing. It's so current and just in time for the growth of social media in the news industry.

description: It's September, 2017. Hurricane Irma is sweeping across the State of Florida, but for disgruntled weatherman Bud Bradbury, the heavy storm sets the mood for a sudden surge of powerful emotion. After being mailed a mysterious, morbid VHS tape containing old lost footage of something deeply disturbing, he decides that it's time to take back control of his own life... but his attempt to get noticed might just be the most dangerous mistake of his entire career.
title: Of Late I Think of Christine Chubbuck
